description:
Actinopolyspora xinjiangensis is a species of actinobacteria that was isolated from saline soil collected in the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region of China. It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and halophilic (salt-loving) bacterium that forms branched, septate hyphae.

Some key features of Actinopolyspora xinjiangensis:

1. Cell morphology: It has a filamentous growth pattern, forming extensively branched hyphae that are divided by cross-walls (septa).

2. Staining and cell wall: As an actinobacterium, it is Gram-positive and has a cell wall typical of this group of bacteria.

3. Physiology: It is halophilic, requiring high salt concentrations (5-20% NaCl) for optimal growth. It is also aerobic, meaning it requires oxygen for respiration.

4. Pigmentation: Colonies of Actinopolyspora xinjiangensis are yellowish-white to pale yellow in color.

5. Phylogeny: Based on 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis, Actinopolyspora xinjiangensis is closely related to other Actinopolyspora species and belongs to the family Nocardiopsaceae within the phylum Actinobacteria.

This species was first isolated and described in 2004 from a saline soil sample, highlighting its adaptation to the high-salinity environment of the Xinjiang region in northwestern China.
